title: 115_hr2189
content: The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act aims to focus the resources of the United States International Trade Commission on protecting domestic industries, ensuring it does not duplicate the role of enforcing intellectual property rights already handled by US district courts. It also seeks to safeguard public health, welfare, and the US economy. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act aims to amend Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include substantial investment in licensing activities that lead to the development of articles incorporating intellectual property rights. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act seeks to amend Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 by specifying that complainants cannot rely on activities by their licensees unless the license results in the creation of products incorporating the claimed intellectual property for sale in the United States. Additionally, the amendment requires individuals to join a complaint under oath to qualify as an industry under subsection (a)(2). The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act proposes amendments to Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930, including requiring complainants to join a complaint under oath to qualify as an industry and setting specific timeframes for expedited fact finding and hearings in investigations. If a domestic industry is identified as a key issue, an expedited fact finding process and early evidentiary hearing must be conducted, with an initial determination required within 100 days of the investigation being initiated. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act proposes amendments to Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930, including specific timeframes for expedited fact finding and hearings in investigations. An initial determination must be made within 100 days of the investigation being initiated, and any determination by the administrative law judge shall stay the investigation pending Commission action. The Act allows for termination of investigations if exclusion of articles is not in the public interest, considering various factors. Any person affected by a ruling of the Commission may appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit within 60 days. The Commission must stay all further proceedings upon appeal. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act suggests changes to Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930, including expedited fact finding and hearings. The Commission can exclude articles if it finds a violation of the section and it is in the public interest. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act proposes amendments to Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930, allowing the Commission to exclude imported articles if a violation is found to be detrimental to public health, the economy, and consumer interests. The Commission may direct exclusion of imported articles if a violation is found to be detrimental to public health, economy, and consumer interests. The Commission may issue a cease and desist order to any person violating unfair methods or acts, considering various factors including public health, economy, and consumer interests. The Commission may issue an exclusion or cease and desist order based on a complaint, with consideration for public health, economy, competitive conditions, and consumer interests. The amendments apply to complaints filed under section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 after the enactment of this Act.
